instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
No visible liquid damage. No prior history available. Came from another shop, found some components knocked off and replaced them(<CAPACITOR>C7981</CAPACITOR> - CPUVCCIOS0_EN, <DIODE>D5802</DIODE> – <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5_R</SIGNAL>, and <CAPACITOR>C4520</CAPACITOR> – <SIGNAL>SATA_ODD_R2D_C_N</SIGNAL>)
I get green light, charges battery(amber), smc reset functions. No fan spin or power. Any ideas? <SIGNAL>18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing, S3 rails missing. Does <SIGNAL>18V5_S5</SIGNAL> supply <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>? Or vice versa?
P3v42 = 3.445v
Ppbus g3h = 12.54v
<SIGNAL>HS_S5_OTHER</SIGNAL> = 12.54v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.39v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL>/R = 0v
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v; _s4 = 3.3v; _s3 = 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v; _s3 = 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> = 3.43v

Any ideas where to start?

EDIT: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: 51125 getting slightly warm when plugged in... replace?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Check if there are short pulses on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>, L7260. Best to check with scope as multimeter is slow and will be hard to catch. 

51125 getting warm is probably normal if you can feel it with your lips. Usually your finger cannot detect it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I didn't detect any spikes with my multi meter, which is usually pretty decent. I have a really old oscilliscope but I don't really know how to use it. Its a tektronix tas 465, ill try to figure it out and update

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: So I think I figured out how to use the oscilloscope, since I am able to get accurate readings on the lines that work. <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> seems to remain at 0v, i've tried various trigger settings and sec/div

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
While you have the scope out check if there is 32KHz on pin 12 of <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. Also check voltages on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03.
The knocked off parts are worrying, what else can be missing that you haven't noticed.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I actually have a multimeter with hz and it does indeed read 32.77k hz. I wish I knew how to check on my oscilliscope, but mine is a dinosaur. Analog from early 90s I believe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Whoops, I got distracted trying to learn to read hz in the oscilloscope, which I did manage. I see 3.29v on each of <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Well, at this point it could be anything. As I said the knocked off parts are worrying as there could be more missing. Possible crap under SMC maybe? More knocked/damaged parts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I just tried replacing the smc from an identical model and same result. Also, thoroughly went through the board a few  times to verify no other components are missing. I wish I knew what the other person did with the board. It didn't look like itd been worked on due to the  typical dust I see on unworked boards. Guess I'll just put this one asked and try some other testing in the future. Thank you again, Duke!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Did you check all rails for shorts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I finally found something significant, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> appears to be welded to the board, trying to remove it tomorrow. I haven't been able to find any shorts either. Probably another time-wasting board. Might just use it as a donor seeing that most of it is in good condition.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> would only affect PPBUS. Seeing that is at 12.6V it is not the problem probably. Even if it caused problem the board should still power from a charged battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Could a bad bios cause no power/fan spin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light No Power/Fan - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S5</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
It would cause power cycling which can be perceived as no power as the pulsing is hard to catch on most multimeters. Best to use a scope and see if any power is coming on/off quickly.
If the BIOS was not touched I would not really suspect it.
